item.title: A Husband Loses His 'Best Friend' — Salome Karwah, Ebola Hero
item.description: March 1, 2017 - She survived the virus and made the cover of Time magazine as an 'Ebola fighter.' Now she's dead at 28, leaving behind a husband and their four young children.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 1, 2017 - She survived the virus and made the cover of Time magazine as an 'Ebola fighter.' Now she's dead at 28, leaving behind a husband and their four young children. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/03/01/515822228/a-husband-loses-his-best-friend-salome-karwah-ebola-hero

item.title: Just How Much Pee Is In That Pool?
item.description: March 1, 2017 - Scientists have now identified an easy way to measure pool urine—by looking for traces of a common artificial sweetener. Urine in pools mixed with chemicals can pose a potential health threat.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 1, 2017 - Scientists have now identified an easy way to measure pool urine—by looking for traces of a common artificial sweetener. Urine in pools mixed with chemicals can pose a potential health threat. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/01/517785902/just-how-much-pee-is-in-that-pool

item.title: Some See 'Flat-Fee Primary Care' As A GOP-Friendly Way To Provide Routine Care
item.description: March 1, 2017 - In "direct primary care," a model favored by HHS Secretary Tom Price, patients pay a monthly fee to doctors for basic health care. But does that really provide better value?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 1, 2017 - In "direct primary care," a model favored by HHS Secretary Tom Price, patients pay a monthly fee to doctors for basic health care. But does that really provide better value? http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/01/517761293/some-see-flat-fee-primary-care-as-a-gop-friendly-way-to-provide-routine-care

item.title: Trump Moves Toward Traditional Republican Health Care Plans
item.description: March 1, 2017 - President Trump doubled down on his pledge to quickly repeal and replace Obamacare. He talked about the longtime Republican idea of having health insurers sell insurance across state lines.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 1, 2017 - President Trump doubled down on his pledge to quickly repeal and replace Obamacare. He talked about the longtime Republican idea of having health insurers sell insurance across state lines. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/01/517882208/trump-moves-toward-traditional-republican-health-care-plans

item.title: What If You Could Take It With You? Health Insurance, That Is
item.description: February 28, 2017 - A key part of GOP plans to reform health care may include making health care more portable. But it's not so easy to do.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 28, 2017 - A key part of GOP plans to reform health care may include making health care more portable. But it's not so easy to do. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/28/517720563/what-if-you-could-take-it-with-you-health-insurance-that-is

item.title: 'River On Fire' Explores Genius, Madness And The Poetry Of Robert Lowell
item.description: February 28, 2017 - Kay Redfield Jamison's new book describes how Lowell's manic-depressive illness influenced his life and work. "His manias tended to lead him into writing a fresh kind of poetry," she says.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 28, 2017 - Kay Redfield Jamison's new book describes how Lowell's manic-depressive illness influenced his life and work. "His manias tended to lead him into writing a fresh kind of poetry," she says. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/28/517706249/river-on-fire-explores-genius-madness-and-the-poetry-of-robert-lowell

item.title: Why Are More Young Americans Getting Colon Cancer?
item.description: February 28, 2017 - Data suggests that the rate of colon cancer among people under 50 is on the rise, but there are lots of possible explanations for that. Scientists say teasing out the truth will be tricky.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 28, 2017 - Data suggests that the rate of colon cancer among people under 50 is on the rise, but there are lots of possible explanations for that. Scientists say teasing out the truth will be tricky. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/28/517563769/why-are-more-young-americans-getting-colon-cancer

item.title: WHO's First-Ever List Of The Dirty Dozen Superbugs
item.description: February 28, 2017 - For the first time, the World Health Organization has released a list of 12 bacteria that "pose the greatest threat to human health" because of their antibiotic resistance.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 28, 2017 - For the first time, the World Health Organization has released a list of 12 bacteria that "pose the greatest threat to human health" because of their antibiotic resistance. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/02/28/517529348/whos-first-ever-list-of-the-dirty-dozen-superbugs

item.title: This CEO's Small Insurance Firm Mostly Turned A Profit Under Obamacare. Here's How
item.description: February 28, 2017 - The health law just needs a tuneup, says the CEO of Molina Healthcare, which operates in 12 states and Puerto Rico. The California-based insurer has seen profits, while Humana and Aetna struggled.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 28, 2017 - The health law just needs a tuneup, says the CEO of Molina Healthcare, which operates in 12 states and Puerto Rico. The California-based insurer has seen profits, while Humana and Aetna struggled. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/28/516495579/this-ceos-small-insurance-firm-mostly-turned-a-profit-under-obamacare-heres-how

item.title: To Keep Teens Safe Online, They Need To Learn To Manage Risk
item.description: February 27, 2017 - Teens should be included in efforts to mitigate their online risks, researchers say, but apps focus more on parents controlling access by monitoring and blocking sites.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - Teens should be included in efforts to mitigate their online risks, researchers say, but apps focus more on parents controlling access by monitoring and blocking sites. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/27/517491502/to-keep-teens-safe-online-they-need-to-learn-to-manage-risk

item.title: Your Name Might Shape Your Face, Researchers Say
item.description: February 27, 2017 - Do you look like a Joy? Genes and culture may make it more likely that names and faces align. But researchers say people also may adjust their expressions to match social expectations of their name.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - Do you look like a Joy? Genes and culture may make it more likely that names and faces align. But researchers say people also may adjust their expressions to match social expectations of their name. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/27/517496915/your-name-might-shape-your-face-researchers-say

item.title: Models Are Still Pressured To Be Ultra-Thin, Survey Says
item.description: February 27, 2017 - A majority of models say they're threatened with job loss if they don't shed pounds. Researchers worry this contributes to poor body image and might increase eating disorders among teenage girls.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - A majority of models say they're threatened with job loss if they don't shed pounds. Researchers worry this contributes to poor body image and might increase eating disorders among teenage girls. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/27/517458922/models-are-still-pressured-to-be-ultra-thin-survey-says

item.title: A Medicine That Blunts The Buzz Of Alcohol Can Help Drinkers Cut Back
item.description: February 27, 2017 - Naltrexone was approved to treat alcohol disorders more than 20 years ago. But many doctors still don't know that when combined with counseling it can help people resist the urge to drink too much.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - Naltrexone was approved to treat alcohol disorders more than 20 years ago. But many doctors still don't know that when combined with counseling it can help people resist the urge to drink too much. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/27/516890375/a-medicine-that-blunts-the-buzz-of-alcohol-can-help-drinkers-cut-back

item.title: The Call-In: The Opioid Epidemic And How Opioids Have Affected Your Lives
item.description: February 26, 2017 - The opioid epidemic is growing. Lulu Garcia-Navarro speaks with Jim Barnum, whose brother died after an opioid addiction and Chuck Rosenberg, acting administrator of the DEA.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 26, 2017 - The opioid epidemic is growing. Lulu Garcia-Navarro speaks with Jim Barnum, whose brother died after an opioid addiction and Chuck Rosenberg, acting administrator of the DEA. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/26/517305305/the-call-in-the-opioid-epidemic-and-how-opioids-have-affected-your-lives

item.title: Dentists Work To Ease Patients' Pain With Fewer Opioids
item.description: February 26, 2017 - After minor surgeries, many dentists used to reflexively prescribe quick-acting opioids to relieve a patient's pain. Now they're learning to counsel patients about better, less addictive alternatives.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 26, 2017 - After minor surgeries, many dentists used to reflexively prescribe quick-acting opioids to relieve a patient's pain. Now they're learning to counsel patients about better, less addictive alternatives. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/26/513865623/dentists-work-to-ease-patients-pain-with-fewer-opioids
